thread.title: Trail Blazers exercise team options on CJ McCollum, Mason Plumlee, Noah Vonleh
thread.title_full: Trail Blazers exercise team options on CJ McCollum, Mason Plumlee, Noah Vonleh | OregonLive.com

author: Joe Freeman | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Trail Blazers exercise team options on CJ McCollum, Mason Plumlee, Noah Vonleh
text:
The Trail Blazers have locked up three of their best young prospects for one more season.
The team on Wednesday exercised fourth-year options on Mason Plumlee and CJ McCollum and a third-year option on Noah Vonleh .
The moves, which involve the 2016-17 NBA season, ensure that all three burgeoning young players will play in Portland for at least two more seasons.
McCollum and Plumlee have the inside track to start at shooting guard and center, respectively, this season and the team is hopeful that each player will develop into franchise cornerstones moving forward. Vonleh, 20, is more of a long-term project than McCollum or Plumlee, but the Blazers are enamored with his versatility, athleticism and upside.
The Blazers drafted McCollum, 24, with the No. 10 pick of the 2013 NBA Draft and he seems poised for a breakout season. He's averaged 6.3 points and 1.4 rebounds in 100 games over his first two seasons, but exploded in the final three games of the first round of the 2015 Western Conference playoffs, averaging 25.7 points, 4.0 rebounds and 1.3 steals as the Blazers fell the Memphis Grizzlies.
The Blazers acquired Plumlee, 25, in a trade with the Brooklyn Nets during the NBA Draft in June. In two up-and-down seasons with the Nets, he averaged 8.1 points and 5.4 rebounds in 152 games. The Blazers are hopeful he can emerge as the long-term answer at center.
Vonleh arrived to Portland as the centerpiece of the Nicolas Batum trade with the Charlotte Hornets. The No. 9 pick of the 2014 NBA Draft played sparingly during his rookie season, averaging 3.3 points and 3.4 rebounds in 25 games.
-- Joe Freeman | jfreeman@oregonian.com | 503-294-5183 | @BlazerFreeman
